items.synopsis: In a basement in a Ukrainian village on the Russian border, the remnants of a torture chamber tell a horrifying tale. Those investigating what happened here say the depraved orders came from the top. WARNING: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: When Russians came looking for Vyacheslav, he had already fled. So they took his mum to the torture chamber

title.children: Here's what comes next for Ben Roberts-Smith after losing his defamation battle and reputation

image.altText: Two photos: A bald man with glasses wearing a suit, next to a photo of a man with hair and no glasses wearing a suit

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Dutton calls Roberts-Smith ruling a 'tough day', Joe Biden 'fine' after fall, and another royal wedding. Here's The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chris Masters, one of the investigative journalists at the centre of the Ben Roberts-Smith case, says a judge's dismissal of the former soldier's defamation case highlights the "integrity" of many members of the Australian Defence Force. "Obviously calling out a war hero as a war criminal is very tough for the ADF, but it should be remembered that he was actually called out by many of his colleagues and I think that reflects the integrity that so many of them demonstrate," he says. "You know, it was just not morally wrong for civilians to be executed in Afghanistan — it was actually strategically wrong as well. "It hurt the war effort and a lot of soldiers knew that, and I am glad that they spoke up, and indeed in doing so I think they probably saved their regiment." Masters says he is feeling relieved, and would have been "appalled" if the ruling had gone against the media organisations which reported on Roberts-Smith.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Journalist Chris Masters says Roberts-Smith ruling highlights 'integrity' of ADF

props.alt: A middle-aged man with glasses does a TV interview from their phone.

children.content: (ABC News)
Chris Masters, one of the investigative journalists at the centre of the Ben Roberts-Smith case, says a judge's dismissal of the former soldier's defamation case
highlights the "integrity" of many members of the Australian Defence Force

"Obviously calling out a war hero as a war criminal is very tough for the ADF, but it should be remembered that he was actually called out by many of his colleagues and I think that reflects the integrity that so many of them demonstrate," he says.
"You know, it was just not morally wrong for civilians to be executed in Afghanistan — it was actually strategically wrong as well.
"It hurt the war effort and a lot of soldiers knew that, and I am glad that they spoke up, and indeed in doing so I think they probably saved their regiment."
Masters says he is feeling relieved, and would have been "appalled" if the ruling had gone against the media organisations which reported on Roberts-Smith.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Controversial influencer Andrew Tate has denied fuelling a culture of misogyny in an interview with the BBC. He has also defended his reputation after spending months in a Romanian jail on suspicion of organised crime and human trafficking. Here's a little from the BBC's Lucy Williamson, who conducted the intense interview: "When the BBC put a range of allegations to him — including specific accusations of rape, human trafficking and exploiting women, for which he is being investigated by Romanian prosecutors — he dismissed them. "When pushed on whether his controversial views on women harmed young people, the influencer claimed he was a 'force for good' and that he was "acting under the instruction of God to do good things". "Mr Tate, who has repeatedly expressed his mistrust of traditional media, has a huge following online but his views have until now gone unchallenged in a direct interview like this." Prosecutors have been investigating Tate, his brother Tristan and two Romanian female suspects for suspected human trafficking, rape and forming a criminal gang to sexually exploit women. You can watch a recap of the BBC interview here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Andrew Tate gives first major TV interview since entering house arrest

children.content: Controversial influencer Andrew Tate has denied fuelling a culture of misogyny
in an interview with the BBC.
He has also defended his reputation after spending months in a Romanian jail on suspicion of organised crime and human trafficking.
Here's a little from the BBC's Lucy Williamson, who conducted the intense interview:

"When the BBC put a range of allegations to him — including specific accusations of rape, human trafficking and exploiting women, for which he is being investigated by Romanian prosecutors — he dismissed them.
"When pushed on whether his controversial views on women harmed young people, the influencer claimed he was a 'force for good' and that he was "acting under the instruction of God to do good things".
"Mr Tate, who has repeatedly expressed his mistrust of traditional media, has a huge following online but his views have until now gone unchallenged in a direct interview like this."
Prosecutors have been investigating Tate, his brother Tristan and two Romanian female suspects for
suspected human trafficking, rape and forming a criminal gang to sexually exploit women
You can watch a recap of the BBC interview here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says yesterday's court ruling against war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith was a "tough day for the country", and believes there has been a "significant culture change" at the Australian Defence Force. A defamation case by war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith against three newspapers was dismissed, after a judge found the defence of substantial truth been established over alleged unlawful killings and bullying. Dutton tells Nine's Today show that most Australians hold the Victoria Cross recipient's former SAS regiment in the highest regard, and he believes there has been enormous change in that regiment since Roberts-Smith's time. "I think there has been a significant culture change over the last half a dozen years at least," he says. "You go to visit the regiment in Perth now, there are very few people there who even served in Afghanistan or were involved in conflicts in the Middle East. "The next generation, even one removed, now are serving in the SAS."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says Ben Roberts-Smith ruling was a 'tough day for the country'

props.alt: A bald man with glasses wearing a suit, next to a photo of a man with hair and no glasses wearing a suit

children.content: Peter Dutton and Ben Roberts-Smith.
(ABC News / AAP)
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says yesterday's court ruling against war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith was a "tough day for the country", and
believes there has been a "significant culture change" at the Australian Defence Force.
A defamation case by war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith against three newspapers was dismissed, after
a judge found the defence of substantial truth been established over alleged unlawful killings and bullying

Dutton tells Nine's Today show that most Australians hold the Victoria Cross recipient's former SAS regiment in the highest regard, and he believes there has been enormous change in that regiment since Roberts-Smith's time.
"I think there has been a significant culture change over the last half a dozen years at least," he says.
"You go to visit the regiment in Perth now, there are very few people there who even served in Afghanistan or were involved in conflicts in the Middle East.
"The next generation, even one removed, now are serving in the SAS."

title.children: Wall St gains as debt ceiling deal advances, hopes of Fed rate pause rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX opening will not be the only thing happening at 10am in the east — the Fair Work Commission (FWC) will release its 2023 minimum and award wages determination. The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has asked for a 7% rise to match the most recent March quarter annual inflation figure. The federal government has supported a rise in line with inflation for Australia's lowest paid workers, i.e. those on the minimum wage. That leaves open scope for the FWC to do what it did last year and give workers on awards (there's roughly 2 million of them) a lower pay increase than those on the minimum wage (of which there are a couple of hundred thousand workers). Last year, the FWC gave minimum wage workers a 5.2% pay rise and award wage workers a 4.6% boost. An increase in line with inflation would lift the minimum wage by around $57 a week this year. However, employer groups have called for a much smaller increase to avoid the risk of rising wages creating an upwards spiral in prices and entrenching high inflation. The Australian Industry Group (AiGroup) called for a 3.8% increase in its submission to Fair Work, while the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) asked for a 3.5% rise. All employees will see a 0.5 percentage point rise in the compulsory superannuation guarantee level from 10.5 to 11% of their pay packet.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Minimum and award wages decision from Fair Work Commission at 10am AEST

children.content: The ASX opening will not be the only thing happening at 10am in the east — the
Fair Work Commission (FWC) will release its 2023 minimum and award wages determination
The
Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has asked for a 7% rise
to match the most recent March quarter annual inflation figure.
The
federal government has supported a rise in line with inflation
for Australia's lowest paid workers, i.e. those on the minimum wage.

That leaves open scope for the FWC to do what it did last year and give workers on awards (there's roughly 2 million of them) a lower pay increase than those on the minimum wage (of which there are a couple of hundred thousand workers).
Last year, the FWC gave minimum wage workers a 5.2% pay rise and award wage workers a 4.6% boost.
An increase in line with inflation would lift the minimum wage by around $57 a week this year.
However,
employer groups have called for a much smaller increase
to avoid the risk of rising wages creating an upwards spiral in prices and entrenching high inflation.
The
Australian Industry Group (AiGroup) called for a 3.8% increase
in its submission to Fair Work, while the
Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) asked for a 3.5% rise
All employees will see a 0.5 percentage point rise in the compulsory superannuation guarantee level from 10.5 to 11% of their pay packet.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to another day of market action. There was certainly some sighs of relief overnight on US markets after the House of Representatives passed the debt ceiling deal struck between President Joe Biden and congressional republicans led by Speaker Kevin McCarthy. The deal suspends the debt ceiling until January 1, 2025, in returns for some limits on spending that are estimated to save around $US1.5 trillion over a decade according to the Congressional Budget Office. That deal now looks likely to sail through the Senate, given the US government some breathing space before it threatens to run out of the ability to borrow money again at some point within the next couple of years. Some key economic data was also viewed positively in light of the upbeat sentiment from the debt deal. Private employment data stayed strong and jobless claims remained low but, despite this, wage increases in the US moderated, raising optimism that the Fed can skip a rate rise this month and may even be finished hiking. "Unit labor cost data for the first quarter normally doesn't trigger a reaction. But it signaled a significant improvement," Edward Moya, senior market analyst at OANDA in New York, told Reuters. "The market became confident that, 'wow the Fed rate hike for June is pretty much not happening ' and confidence is falling for raising rates for July." US manufacturing data, including around input costs, was also weak, further adding to the case that price pressures in the economy are easing. Futures are now pricing in a more than three-quarters chance of the Federal Reserve keeping rates on hold when it meets in a couple of weeks. The benchmark S & P 500 index rose 1% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq 1.3%, with both reaching nine-month highs, while the blue chip Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.5% to 33,062 points. Stay with me to see how the Australian share market reacts later this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will shares break their ceiling amid US debt deal?

children.content: Good morning, welcome to another day of market action.
There was certainly some sighs of relief overnight on US markets after
the House of Representatives passed the debt ceiling deal
struck between President Joe Biden and congressional republicans led by Speaker Kevin McCarthy.
The deal
suspends the debt ceiling until January 1, 2025
, in returns for some limits on spending that are estimated to save around $US1.5 trillion over a decade according to the Congressional Budget Office.

That deal now looks likely to sail through the Senate, given the US government some breathing space before it threatens to run out of the ability to borrow money again at some point within the next couple of years.
Some key economic data was also viewed positively in light of the upbeat sentiment from the debt deal.
Private employment data stayed strong and jobless claims remained low
but, despite this,
wage increases in the US moderated
, raising optimism that the Fed can skip a rate rise this month and may even be finished hiking.
"Unit labor cost data for the first quarter normally doesn't trigger a reaction. But it signaled a significant improvement," Edward Moya, senior market analyst at OANDA in New York, told Reuters.
"The market became confident that, 'wow
the Fed rate hike for June is pretty much not happening
' and confidence is falling for raising rates for July."
US manufacturing data, including around input costs, was also weak, further adding to the case that price pressures in the economy are easing.
Futures are now pricing in a more than three-quarters chance of the Federal Reserve keeping rates on hold when it meets in a couple of weeks.
The benchmark S
P 500 index rose 1% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq 1.3%, with both reaching nine-month highs, while the blue chip Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.5% to 33,062 points.
Stay with me to see how the Australian share market reacts later this morning.
